The plant typically grows in coastal areas and has adapted to the unique environmental conditions of Hawaii. Its foliage is usually narrow and grass-like, and it produces small, showy blooms that attract pollinators. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Lastrea dayi is considered a rare and endangered species.
